Understate: The claim may understate the fact that not all parents were asked to sign the COVID-19 liability waiver, only those whose children were participating in summer athletic programs.
Lack enough support: The claim may lack enough support as it does not provide specific evidence or sources to back up the assertion that a Missouri school district asked parents to sign a COVID-19 liability waiver.
Problematic assumption: The claim may make a problematic assumption by implying that the liability waiver was required for the entire 2020-2021 school year, when in fact it was only for summer athletic programs.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim may have an alternative explanation as it does not mention that the liability waiver was a template provided by an insurance provider and that the mention of "death" is common in athletic liability waivers.
Falters at times: The claim may falter at times by focusing on the word "death" and extrapolating language from the waiver without providing the full context of its purpose and scope.
Contradict fact: The claim may contradict the fact that the waiver was not specifically for the academic school year, but for summer athletic programs.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the situation by stating that the waiver went viral after a Twitter user shared it, without providing evidence of its widespread dissemination.
